utterances.sentences: But you seem to be saying right here, Professor, that what Donald Trump did was wrong and troubling, but it wasn't impeachable.

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: No, no, what you said is of a president did it solely for his own interest would it be -- would it be --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I never used the word solely. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: Ok, but I'm using it. If a president had --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What difference does it make if he did it partially?

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: Oh, every president has an eye on electability.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: We're not talking about electability. We're talking but investigating your political rivals.

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: But if a president does it for mixed motives, he says 90 percent of my motive is, I want to get rid of corruption. Let's assume a guy named Joe Biden goes and says to somebody in the Ukraine, unless you stop -- unless you fire the investigator, I'm going to cut off the money. Let's assume 90 percent of what he had in his mind was the public interest. But in the back of his mind, he says, you know, maybe it will help my kid. He works for the company. That would not be impeachable. That would not be corruption. When you have mixed motives, you can't turn innocent conduct into criminal conduct. That was my point. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK, finally, I want to ask you about you, aside from this case --

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- your role and your sense of yourself as a defense lawyer. Over the years, you have represented some pretty controversial figures, I think --

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: To say the least.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: To say the least. O.J. Simpson, Mike Tyson, Jeffrey Epstein. I understand the principle of everyone has a right --

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: -- to a counsel, to defense. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: But why would you spend your time -- why would you spend your talents defending such unsavory characters?

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: Because the Constitution requires that the most despised people, the most controversial people must get a defense. I litigated cases in the Soviet Union and in other places where people who are despised by the public and by the government couldn't get a lawyer, and I decided after being in the Soviet Union, I would never allow public opinion to impact my decision. I would have been --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What about your personal opinion? (INAUDIBLE) about some people that you'd say, you know, they have a right to a defense. I just don't want to be part of it.

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: No, I -- because I was a professor for 50 years and I have no excuse for not taking cases, I want to be part of cases were nobody else can get -- is willing to come in and do the case. I want to be part of controversial cases. This case, I didn't do it for that reason. This case -- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, I'm not -- I'm not talking about this case.

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: This case, I do it because the Constitution was being absolutely compromised in its --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In these other cases. If you end up -- because of your talents, you end up getting them off, your --

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: I hope so. I mean, I never want to take a case where I don't win. I've won a lot of cases because the law or the facts were on my side. Often, the facts are against me, but the law is on my side. Look, to me, my hero was John Adams. Standing up for the people, the murderers in the Boston massacre and accepting all the opprobrium that was heaped upon them because he said, I want to show the king of England that we in America believe that everybody is entitled to a defense. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } He defended them and it almost destroyed his career and his personal life. He did the right thing and I'm going to continue to do that for as long as God gives me the strength to defend people who are guilty, innocent, popular, or unpopular.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Professor Dershowitz, you show no sign of slowing down. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Always good to talk with you, sir.

utterances.speaker: DERSHOWITZ
utterances.sentences: My pleasure. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Up next, countdown to Iowa. Democratic candidate, Senator Amy Klobuchar, joins us live from the campaign trail as she makes a big move late in this race as "FOX News Sunday" continues its coverage of Super Bowl LIV live from Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Florida. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to Miami Gardens, Florida, and Hard Rock Stadium, home of Super Bowl LIV on Fox.  Well, tonight's game is just the first big contest this week. Tomorrow night, thousands of folks in Iowa will go to schools and churches and firehouses across that state to caucus and give us the first results of the Democratic presidential race.  Joining us now from Des Moines, candidate and senator Amy Klobuchar, who's hoping to build on her recent momentum there.  Senator, something interesting is happening in Iowa, and I want to put up the numbers. Back in August you were sitting at 3 percent and you stayed there for quite a while. But in recent weeks you've surged to almost 10 percent, closing in on the top tier. What is going on and where are you going to finish on Monday night?  KLOBUCHAR: You know, it is an open game here, to your Super Bowl analogy. And by the way, congratulations on having the Super Bowl on Fox. It could only be better if the Vikings were in it. But I'm excited to watch the game.  And what's been happening here is there's just a lot of people who are still making their decisions. We were out yesterday everywhere from the Quad Cities to Sioux City to Cedar Falls to Beaverdale. And every place we went, huge crowds, a lot of interest, people literally signing up yesterday, committing to caucus.  So we're excited. We had two polls last week that I was at 13 percent -- or one was at 13 percent. I was third in two polls. And we just see a lot of enthusiasm. I have more endorsements than anyone else in the race when it comes to state legislators.  WALLACE: All right. But...  KLOBUCHAR: So we are really building something.  WALLACE: But, Senator, isn't Iowa, kind of, a special case for you?  You come, as you just pointed out, from right across the border over in Minnesota. You have held 189 events there over 69 days. Don't you have to finish in the top three here in Iowa, or you're done?  And if you do finish in the top three, how can you replicate that in other states like New Hampshire, where you haven't spent nearly as much time?  KLOBUCHAR: Well, first of all, I've been to New Hampshire 22 times, Chris. I just do a lot of stuff. And I -- I literally don't put those kinds of litmus tests. I think we have to do well here.  There's been a lot going on, having been gone the last few weeks that I didn't expect to have happened. But I'm going to New Hampshire no matter what. There's a debate. I'm on the debate stage. I've got the endorsements of every major paper in New Hampshire, including the Union Leader, that have endorsed in New Hampshire. And so of course I'm going there; we have a strong operation there, and then going beyond.  WALLACE: All right...  KLOBUCHAR: I think that my -- but, remember, I bring something to the stage that really no one else has. I'm one of only two candidates from the middle of the country, where we need to win as Democrats. I'm someone that's won with moderate Republicans and independents in the reddest of red congressional districts, over and over again. Because I bring people with me.  I'm the only one that has those receipts that I can bring into this election. I'm one of two women that are left on the debate stage. I'm someone that has passed over 100 bills as a lead democrat.  WALLACE: OK...  KLOBUCHAR: There's a lot of stuff about why I should stay in this race, and I'm excited to be one of the leading candidates. WALLACE: You've made it very clear you're staying in the race.  (LAUGHTER)  Let me ask you, because Iowa and the caucuses have special rules, and one of them is, if you don't have 15 percent of the people who show up at an individual precinct caucus, then you don't qualify; you don't get any delicates and -- you know, at the caucus level, at the precinct level.  And there has been talk -- and I want to find out if it's true -- that the Biden campaign has come to your campaign and said, "Let's make a deal" -- like the TV show -- "If one of us doesn't have -- meet the 15 percent threshold, we'll put our candidates in the other one's camp so that they can get the benefit of that."  One, is it true? Did they try to make a deal with you to switch votes if somebody falls short? And if so, are you going to accept that?  KLOBUCHAR: No deals. In fact, they just approached someone who was affiliated with our campaign but not on our staff, and some evening in Des Moines asked them about it. He said no. We said no. There is no deal.  And I am just focused on our own race here. We have precinct captains all over the state. We have worked on this, and we are really excited.  And also, remember the rural issues. I serve on the Agriculture Committee. I have a long track record of working on rural issues. So I have something that's pretty special here going into the Iowa caucuses. And we're excited about how we're doing.  WALLACE: Senator, a new issue has come up in the last few days I want to ask you about. Back in 2003, you were the top prosecutor for Hennepin County in Minnesota and your office put a 16-year-old boy in prison for life for the shooting of a young girl.  You've campaigned on how this shows that you are tough on crime. But just in the last few days -- I want to put this up on the screen -- a year-long Associated Press investigation has raised new questions about whether that young man was wrongfully convicted. They found police offered cash to potential witnesses and relied on testimony from jailhouse informants who got reduced sentences.  Senator, did you know -- when you were the prosecutor, did you know about any of that? And should this man's case be reopened?  KLOBUCHAR: Well, justice must be done, Chris. And just to put it in some context, this was an 11-year-old girl named Tyesha Edwards. She was doing her homework at her kitchen table and a bullet went through the wall and she died. And it was a tragic case. It was a big deal within the African- American community. And our focus was on bringing the people to justice and doing justice for her family. So what happened was...  WALLACE: But...  KLOBUCHAR: ... three people were convicted -- if I could just finish...  WALLACE: But, Senator...  KLOBUCHAR: ... and now one...  WALLACE: We know -- let me just say, we know it was a bad case. The question is whether this young man did it. And this AP investigation...  KLOBUCHAR: Exactly.  WALLACE: ... indicates that other people who were there said he didn't do it and that some of the witnesses that were relied on were very questionable. You were the head prosecutor. Did you know? And if you didn't, shouldn't you have known?  KLOBUCHAR: There actually were two trials in this case, Chris. One was after I was -- had left the office.  WALLACE: But he was convicted in the case when you were the prosecutor.  KLOBUCHAR: I know. Could I just -- if I could just answer. My view, as someone that has worked with the Innocence Project for years, is that, if there is new evidence, it must come forward; it must come forward, and it must be considered immediately by the court. The job of a prosecutor is to do justice. And that means to me convict the guilty; protect the innocent; do your job without fear or favor...  (CROSSTALK)  KLOBUCHAR: And that's what I have asked to happen.  WALLACE: Senator, you're not answering my question.  KLOBUCHAR: OK. OK.  WALLACE: Did you know about the fact that there was this questionable evidence that the police were coming up with?  KLOBUCHAR: I didn't know about this new evidence, no. I didn't know about this new evidence until I saw this report. I -- I couldn't have. I haven't been in the office for 12 years.  WALLACE: I -- I -- but I was wondering, when you were in the office, did you know about this questionable evidence?  I -- the reason I'm asking you is, as I'm sure you well know now, there are a number of African-American groups in Minnesota who are calling for you to suspend your campaign until this is cleared up. And according to national polls, you're below 1 percent in African-American support. You're not going to win the Democratic nomination if you have such little support from the minority community.  KLOBUCHAR: Well, I think what you've seen all across the country is that, when people get to know me, I do well. And it's on me. I've got to go out there and -- and get to know people. And in my case, let's look at Iowa. Two prominent African-American legislators have endorsed me, are out campaigning for me right this weekend.  At home, I've always enjoyed and have gotten strong support within the African-American community. I've been a leader on issues with the Somali community in my home state. And it's on me to go across the country and make the case for my agenda, which is very strong when it comes to the African-American community.  WALLACE: Right...  KLOBUCHAR: It's about economic opportunity. It's about voting rights. I've been the lead on things like getting rid of gerrymandering and getting rid of voting purges. Those are my bills that I've led on. And so that's on me, and I will keep criss-crossing the country, make my case to the African- American community, as I've done right here in Iowa.  WALLACE: Senator Klobuchar, thank you. Thanks for your time. And good luck tomorrow night.  KLOBUCHAR: Thank you. Thank you very much.  WALLACE: When we come back, we will bring in our Sunday political panel in Iowa. What should we expect from tomorrow's caucuses? And could there be some big surprises? We're live for Miami Gardens as FOX Sports at the beach to cover tonight's Super Bowl. We will be right back.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Coming up, last-minute campaigning in Iowa as the 2020 Democrats make their final cases ahead of tomorrow's vote.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: I'm asking you to consider caucusing for me. I need your help.

utterances.speaker: PETE BUTTIGIEG (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: I'm here eye to eye to ask you to caucus for me on February 3rd.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: We'll have a special Sunday group live from Iowa. That's next on "FOX News Sunday".

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: I call it the impeachment hoax, and that's what it is, it's a hoax. It should have never taken place, should have never been allowed to happen. But I have great confidence in Republican senators and probably some Democrats from what I understand.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS WALLACE, FOX HOST
utterances.sentences: President Trump talking with Peter Doocy this week in Iowa about the Senate impeachment trial. And it's time now for our Iowa panel. Fox News senior political analyst Brit Hume, Marie Harf, executive director of the Serve America PAC, and GOP strategist Karl Rove. Well, Brit, I think it's clear from the start that President Trump was never going to be removed from office in this process, but as we wrap up impeachment and the Senate trial, who do you think has the political advantage in the -- particularly as we look to November, both in the race for the White House and the race in Congress, Republicans or Democrats?

utterances.speaker: BRIT HUME, FOX NEWS SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Well, I think it's a little hard to say at this point, Chris, because it's not clear how much attention the public was paying to this. Indications are the public really wasn't following it nearly as closely as -- as we in Washington and in the media generally were -- were following it. So we don't know whether it will have very much impact at all. My suspicion is it will have less impact that -- than any of the impeachment or impeachment investigations of presidents that we've recently seen. And I don't think that any of these Republican senators, by the way they've behaved, are afraid at all that their political forces are going to be harmed by voting not only not to have witnesses, but inevitably to acquit. So my sense of it is that this could end up being kind of a political wash.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Marie, do you think that House Democrats have any second thoughts about, one, going for impeachment, and, two, deciding not to fight in court, even if it was going to take a while, to try to get John Bolton to testify in the House?

utterances.speaker: MARIE HARF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Well, Chris, it was a big of a catch 22 because the White House made clear they had no intention of participating in this process and House Democrats felt like they had a strong enough case as is. I happen to agree. There will be a lot of hand-wringing probably in Democratic circles about this over the coming days and weeks. But I think what it's shown Democrats in this election cycle is that, first, it is so important to nominate someone who can beat Donald Trump in November because the president will probably feel emboldened and even more unfettered after this acquittal and also that they need to focus down ballot on Senate races because no matter what had happened with John Bolton or witnesses, because we don't have the majority in the Senate, we were always going to lose this impeachment fight. And so here in Iowa, Joni Ernst is on the ballot in November. Senders like Cory Gardner and Martha McSally, already facing tough races holding onto their Republican seats, that's where Democrats are focused and feel like impeachment actually may help pick up some Senate seats in November.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Karl, as we pointed out, Donald Trump is going to be delivering the State of the Union Address to a joint session of Congress on Tuesday night and, like Bill Clinton back in 1999, he'll be delivering that, even though it's only one day away from acquittal while the Senate impeachment trial is still going on. If you were advising him, if you were in the role you were in with Bush 43, would you -- how would you tell him to handle impeachment in the Senate trial? How aggressively should he go at Democrats for what they have put him and the country through?

utterances.speaker: KARL ROVE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Well, the less said about it I think in the State of the Union Address the better off for President Trump. More important to herald what he's achieved. And we've heard that he's going to be talking about the blue-collar economic prosperity. And also to sort of lift the curtain on the second act, what does he intend to do both in the balance of the year and in his -- in -- and leave the impression it would - - things that he would tackle in a second term. Tomorrow night is a valuable moment for him. It is a moment where he can sort of be dismissive of the impeachment by giving it as little attention in his remarks as possible and putting the focus on what he's done and what he intends to do.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right, let's turn to why you guys are all in Des Moines and I should point out, off-camera Karl pointed out the temperature disparity between Des Moines and Miami. Karl, I'm sorry you drew the short straw. Although Des Moines is a lovely place. But -- there it is. 43 degrees in Des Moines, 66 --

utterances.speaker: ROVE
utterances.sentences: Yes --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I will tell you, it is unseasonably cold here in Miami, so we're - - we're actually not that happy here.

utterances.speaker: ROVE
utterances.sentences: Oh, you're suffering. We feel -- we feel so sorry for you to be suffering a Miami Gardens. Really. Seriously.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right. In any case, let's turn to Iowa --

utterances.speaker: ROVE
utterances.sentences: Can we send you a care package?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Let's talk about the two frontrunners in this race who are going at each other. Here's an example.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: Bernie is a -- he calls himself a Democratic socialist. We have a different view on a whole lot of things. He's a decent guy. I don't think he should be running.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (I-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: Well, Joe Biden has been on the floor of the Senate talking about the need to cut Social Security or Medicare or Medicaid.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Karl, as you sit there today, Sunday, do you have any sense who is going to win the Iowa caucuses tomorrow night?

utterances.speaker: ROVE
utterances.sentences: No. No real idea. And, look, I think -- I think we're going to have multiple winners tomorrow night. This is not going to be 2000 where Al Gore blows out Bradley 60 some odd to 35 percent and the contest is over. The closest thing we have is some of the contests like 2008 where there -- it was relatively close, or 2016 where it was 49.8 to 49.8, literally a couple hundred votes separating Clinton and Sanders and it forecast a contest that went to the end of June. And I think we're going to have that kind of a contest tomorrow night.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So let me --

utterances.speaker: ROVE
utterances.sentences: I would not be surprised to see three or four candidates splitting up the delegate pool. I wouldn't even be surprised if five candidates shared in the 41 delegates to be awarded in Iowa.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So -- so let's pick up on that, Marie. Assuming that it's kind of muddled and maybe one person wins the popular vote and somebody else wins the delegate vote, how much does Iowa matter as we all get on the train or the bus and head to New Hampshire the next day?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I think as long as there are no huge surprises, nobody really underperforming or over performing, it will probably end up muddled and we'll going into New Hampshire expecting Bernie Sanders to win there, expecting Joe Biden to win in Nevada and South Carolina and then looking to see how Mike Bloomberg will do on Super Tuesday. Joe Biden does need to perform strongly here in Iowa because of the expectations. He needs to demonstrate that he is the moderate choice that is in the primary against the Bernie/Warren wing of it. And so I think that where Amy Klobuchar's voters go potentially on a second ballot, if she doesn't make the threshold, if they go to Joe Biden --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Let me --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: If Mayor Pete doesn't, where his voters go. That's what we're really going to be watching here.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Marie, let me bring in -- we're wanting out of time. Let me bring in Brit. I've got about a minute and a half left. I -- you know, I can make a scenario that this is shaping up pretty well for Mike Bloomberg. You could have a pretty muddled field coming out of Iowa, maybe New Hampshire. The DNC has just changed its rules so that Bloomberg is going to be able to get on the stage likely for the next debate. How seriously should we take Mayor Mike?

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: I think we should take Mayor Mike quite seriously. I think he's a genuine wildcard in the race. And remember, Chris, we are seeing money spent by him in this race that is orders of magnitude greater than anything we have ever seen. And if you get a muddled picture, particularly one with Bernie Sanders getting an edge out of Iowa and perhaps New Hampshire as well, I think that strengthens the case for Bloomberg because frightened centrist Democrats and moderate Democrats, to the extent that there are any, will be terrified of Sanders, terrified of a major defeat at his hands and I think that at that point, Bloomberg, with all his money, becomes a potential factor. We don't know that. Nothing's ever -- like this has never been tried before. When people wait to get into late races, that has never worked before. But this is altogether different because we're seeing money on a scale we've never seen before.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And let me just point out, panel, I was talking to a big Republican who is here for the Super Bowl and he said the one advice he's giving to President Trump is don't tweet about Mike Bloomberg. All you do is elevate him. And last night, and you can check it out, Donald Trump was tweeting about Mike Bloomberg. Thank you, panel. See you next Sunday in New Hampshire, where it will be a lot colder than it is here. Up next, the highlights every time we report from the Super Bowl. We sit on with the hosts of "FOX NFL SUNDAY" and, yes, once again it gets out of hand.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That's a look at the massive Fox Sports and media compound on South Beach ahead of tonight's big game. Earlier, we got the chance to sit down again with a "FOX NFL SUNDAY" crew, Terry, Howie, Michael, and Jimmy. And, once again, it got rowdy.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So, it has taken me three years to recover from our last encounter. Are you as excited to see me as I am to see all of you? TERRY BRADSHAW, "FOX NFL SUNDAY" HOST: No. No. HOWIE LONG, "FOX NFL SUNDAY" HOST: Always excited. MICHAEL STRAHAN, "FOX NFL SUNDAY" HOST : More excited!

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: No, I'm not and I know he isn't. JIMMY JOHNSON, "FOX NFL SUNDAY" HOST: Oh, no, no, I'm really excited. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Oh, you're excited. OK, I'm --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Let's get --

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: You're the only guy that's on TV more than Michael right now with all these hearings --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, nobody's on TV more than Michael.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Well, Jimmy dressed up for you, by the way.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I know that. I was going to say, you guys didn't dress up. All right, let's start with the game. The -- it seems to me one of the storylines here is generational change. No Tom Brady. No Bill Belichick. New faces. New teams. Howie, is that good for the game?

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do. And I think we always -- we always wonder who's going to replace -- whether it's Terry Bradshaw, Joe Montana, John Elway and his -- this kid in Kansas City is a guy that if he pulls this thing off might be the face of the NFL. And we're going to see a lot of kids out there trying to emulate him in Pop Warner football and the sidearm throws, the --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: The no look throws.

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: The left-handed throws.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Let me pick up that with you, TB, because --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: TB. TB. Do you hear it?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, we're -- come on, we're -- we're besties.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Hey there, bubba.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy, that was awkward.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Hey, stop laughing!

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: That was awkward.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So, anyway, I think that Mahomes is the most dynamic, most exciting player in the game. As somebody who knows even more about quarterbacking than I do, what you think?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Well, he is -- there is a kid -- Lamar Jackson in Baltimore --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Who's as equally as exciting, only in a different way.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Not only can he throw the football, but he -- he's electrifying as a runner also.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: So he is -- he is -- I would put them one a and one b, you'd go whichever one you -- way you want to go. But I -- but Mahomes -- hey, listen, I have such great respect and admiration for him that we had a horse born the other day and we -- my wife named him Homes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Homes.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Because she's from Kansas City. Homes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Oh, OK. All right.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: So, there you go. That says it all.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: You -- you sure know how to bring a horse or a cow story into every game.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Always promoting, Mike. Always, the wife --

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: It's amazing. It's really amazing.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So, Michael, you've got this turbocharged Kansas City offense against this stiff, stubborn San Francisco defense. How do you handicap that?

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, man. I -- you -- think when you're a defensive player and how you always feel like defense wins in a lot of ways because they always say the best -- the best counter to a great passing game is a pass rush. You know, that helps out the coverage. I think the unique thing the 49ers have, four guys who can get after the quarterbacks and you can drop seven. They take away so much worry on the back end of this defense but Kansas City, you're going against some of the fastest receivers in the games and the most electric receivers in the game and also a running back in Williams, who had to that coming out of the back for another (ph) receiver. This is going to be as TB -- I don't even know. It's going to be a hard day --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Hey, see, he gets away with it. You don't laugh at him, TB.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: It's such a hard game to -- it's such pick. And you know the other day I had a puppy and I --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What was the puppy's name, Michael? Raheem.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Homes (INAUDIBLE). The puppy's name is Jimmy G.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, let me ask Jimmy Johnson, because one of the other storylines in this is Andy Reid, who is the winningest coach in the NFL history who has not won a Super Bowl. And the story is that everybody outside of San Francisco is rooting for Andy Reid to win the Super Bowl. Is that true? And, if so, why?

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Chris, I really think so because he is such a nice guy. Any -- you know --

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Anybody that knows him personally, anybody that's ever met him, you know, they all say, you know, Andy Reid is one of the nicest people you'll ever want to meet. And so even though people are people supposed to be unbiased, you know, really they're pulling for Andy Reid to win the Super Bowl. And you talk to those players. You know, I -- I talked with him the other day. I said, you know, looking at it, you know, your players like you. They don't just play for you, they like you. I don't know that they ever liked me. Now, they respected me, but I don't know about -- if they really liked me.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: You want me to answer that?

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: I say your --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, answer that, Michael.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Supposed to jump in and -- you jump in and say they liked him.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: They didn't like him.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: They didn't like him?

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: No --

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: No, they respected him, but they didn't like him. He was a mean man.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Hey --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: And Jimmy Johnson would scare me if I was playing for Jimmy Johnson.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, I used to love playing -- I'd play in fear for Jimmy.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK, so now let me look at it from the other side. Howie, in the NFC championship game, you're looking at me like you're a little surprised I know this much about it. Jimmy Garoppolo --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: It's written down, for God's sake.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I wrote it.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: You're reading it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Jimmy Garoppolo ran -- threw the ball eight times. Can he get through this Super Bowl and win it throwing the ball eight times?

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: You know, I think he benefited a great deal from being in New England, just through osmosis. I think, you know, you -- he's bound to have picked something up from Tom Brady and Bill Belichick and I think it's something that he's used earlier in the year. You talk about the New Orleans games, four touchdown passes in that game and I think Jimmy's willing to win whatever way he has to. And I think that's key. And I think that's part of his New England background. That's in his DNA.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: I don't think you're going to win going in --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Here's what's got everybody confused. They're looking at the last two games. The playoff games where he ran the ball in one game 47 times.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: But let me explain something. He -- he averaged 285 yards a game this year and Mahomes, 301. And he had 28 touchdowns. The other guy had 30 (ph). He's playing with --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Have you got this written down somewhere?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: I -- no, bub, it's right here.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: This is what I do for a living.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Bub?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Bub.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I have -- you know, nobody's called me that in a couple of weeks.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: If I call you bub, you're in my circle, OK?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK. All right.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: But this --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I'm your man. I am your Mahomey?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: You are my Mahomey.

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: Once it's in there, nothing gets out there.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: This is awkward, the longer this goes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right, so, Michael, let me ask you a series football question. Rahim -- I'm not looking. Raheem Mostert ran for 220 yards in the NFC championship game. I checked -- I did check this out. Since 2015, he has been on eight NFL teams. So -- and he looks like Jim Brown suddenly.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So how does he emerge like this?

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Because I think he's in an offense that fits him well. And they've have a three headed running back by running back by committee. And when his number's being called, he's taking advantage of it. But any guy who's been on that many teams and you get an opportunity, you're not letting it pass. He's running as if his life depends on it because his football life does. And the way he's representing himself now, if -- if he's not on the 49ers, there are so many other teams right there who will take this kid because it's good to see a story like this. This is a great storyline for the NFL, for all those kids out there who may not be the best now, who may feel like they're on the verge of, you know, not making a team, that once you are -- you get cut or once you -- you're not - - you get let go, don't give up. He's a great -- great model for that.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Yes, he was a special teams guy and by people getting hurt he got his chance to play and he's -- he's --

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: It's an amazing story.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, incredible story.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It is an amazing story. And I'm glad that I knew in and asked you guys about it. There you go. You're my Mahomey.

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: Mahomey.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right, Jimmy, so --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Do you do this with the senators?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Exactly. Off-camera. Listen -- would you stop laughing at me?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I'm glad I'm entertaining you, Howie. I'm glad -- he's turning red with laughter. So, Jimmy --

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: Oh, we laugh a lot.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Keys to the game. It's for the folks sitting out there, first quarter, what's going to say to them, well, you know, this is looking Kansas City or, no, this is looking --

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Well, you look at Kansas City the last couple of ball games, they've come from behind. You know, they got behind against Tennessee. They got behind -- you know, the -- they can come from behind and score lots of points. And I had to go against you here, Michael, and I said, you know, and coaching all those years, I would've gone defense. But Patrick Mahomes, he is so talented. I think he may offset that defense. He can make things happen that no other quarterback can make happen.

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: See, he went to -- he went to their practice.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: He spoke to the teams.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, so he's biased (ph).

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: He gave them a big pep talk.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: They like him? They like him?

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: He's a Kansas City guy. He's got to go now.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Oh, Coach Johnson. Oh.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: But I'll tell you right now, you better not -- you said they -- he said they started slow. They got behind. If they get behind 21 points like they did against Houston, or they get behind 10 points, like they did in the last game --

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Did you think --

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: I don't know if you come back against this defense --

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Because they will run the ball to keep your offense off the field.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: I don't know --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Most teams that are able to come from behind are playing against teams that go into zones. Zones allow you to move the ball, all right? Man- to-man, you can go fast and this team in San Francisco, you get behind, they come -- they're going to pour it on you.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: No, TB, you know, those players for Kansas City will recall what I told them at practice.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Pep talk.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Did you --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Wait a minute, you gave them a pep talk and you didn't give the 49ers a pep talk?

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: No, he did not.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: We have a little --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That would be like me giving the Democrats a pep talk and not the Republicans.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Well, no, no, no, no. We have a contest here on "FOX NFL SUNDAY."

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: True that.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: We have a contest.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: True that.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: And I'm the lead dog. I'm the lead dog. Been lead dog all year long.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: And we can always take it back to you.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK, wait, wait, I -- I -- wait -- I've got to -- we're running out of time and I know you'd like to talk to me all afternoon, but the big story to me and the thing I was most excited about sitting down with you is that you are now a member of the Hall of Fame.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Amen.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I watched when you got the announcement here on this show. Frankly, you blubbered like a baby.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Oh!

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: Oh!

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Oh!

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: No, no, what -- what -- I just want to ask, why does it mean so much to you?

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: When you coach for 40 years --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: It's nice to be recognized. You know, actually, when I was coaching, I didn't care anything about individual awards. It's a team game. But now that I've been out for so long, having coached that amount of time, and plus with these guys, the people I love right up here, they're all Hall of Famers. So I wanted to be a Hall of Famer too.

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Nice.

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: Ad deservedly so.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Are you in the Hall of Fame, by the way?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I'm not in anybody's Hall of Fame.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: I can't believe they let you come out here and do this interview.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I'm not -- I'm not. All right, so --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Where did you go to high school?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Three years from now --

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Oh!

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Hey, guess what, the interview's done, I don't care. You can have it. I'll sign it for you. Thank you. So, three years from now, when we're doing it again, Fox, the Super Bowl is in Phoenix, in Arizona. Their babies. They're going to be there. The question is, are you and I going to be there three years from now?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm -- I plan on being there. Why wouldn't I be there?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: I'm 71. How old are you?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: OK. I -- I got better a chance then you then.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You're -- wait a minute, you -- when you were winning all those games with Pittsburgh, you were younger than I was?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: One year it looks like.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Say goodnight, Gracie, we're done.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: No, you (INAUDIBLE). Who are you picking in the game?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Look, you guys don't tell ahead of time.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm -- I will tell you. who you picking?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right. You're going to tell first?

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: I'll go 49ers. Who you going with?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Kansas City.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Well, that's the dumbest pick I ever heard in my life.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Jimmy, you want to say?

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: Hey, bub, you and I, Kansas City.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Oh, wait a minute, you're not supposed to -- Howie?

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: I'll make my pick on Sunday.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Oh. Michael?

utterances.speaker: STRAHAN
utterances.sentences: Same as that. Saving mine for Sunday. But I've got to say, this is the most fun interview we've done all week.

utterances.speaker: LONG
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's good. Fist pump (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: There you go, man. Mahomey.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: They're Mahomey.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: Mahomey.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: True that, baby.

utterances.speaker: BRADSHAW
utterances.sentences: True that.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Hey, mike dropped.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my. Up next, our "Power Player of the Week." He pulled off one of the most famous plays in football and we'll ask Hall of Famer Franco Harris about the immaculate reception and what he thinks about another big contest as FOX NEWS SUNDAY reports from Hard Rock Stadium live in Miami Gardens ahead of Super Bowl LIV.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: One of the best parts of going to the Super Bowl is before the game when you see football giants walking down the street. Well, yesterday, I sat down with Pittsburgh Steelers Hall of Fame running back Franco Harris and he's our "Power Player of the Week."

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So, Franco, I've got to tell you, I was talking to Dana Perino yesterday and I said I'm talking to Franco Harris, and she said Frank O'Harris (ph). And she --

utterances.speaker: FRANCO HARRIS, NFL HALL OF FAMER
utterances.sentences: I get that all the time. And I tell people, that's why the (INAUDIBLE) drafted me, they thought my name was Frank O'Harris.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: They thought you were Irish?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: They thought I was Irish. And whala (ph).

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It worked out. OK. This is the NFL's 100 season and the league says that the greatest play in the 100 years is your catch, the immaculate reception, back in the playoff game in 1972. Why do you think that play still resonates 48 years later?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Because the Steelers, before that year, the Steelers always found a way to lose. They were known as SOS, same old Steelers found a way to lose. And on that play, we were winning and then were losing again. But, guess what? We found a way to win.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And that's it.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: And -- and --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You can find a way to win.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Find a way to win and that's been carried over with the Steelers ever since.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You say that that play happened because you had been trained by Coach Paterno at Penn State.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Always go to the ball.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Go to the ball. And during that play, when Bradshaw was scrambling, and he threw the ball, I said, go to the ball. And it's amazing what can happen.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So --

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: So, thank you, Joe.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Over the years you have supported a lot of causes, education, scholarships for kids in public schools, programs for poor people like energy assistance, Special Olympics. How important for you to have this platform of the NFL has given you so you can help people?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: You know what, the NFL has given me an unbelievable platform. And if my voice can make a difference, then I look at that platform as being something more than just football

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: This is a political talk show, so I'm going to ask you one, quick political question. I know you're a big Democrat. Do you have a candidate for 2020?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: You know what, as you know, I will get behind one. And I like it every four years we compete. I love to compete. And whoever wins, wins, that's my president, right? And -- but then ever four -- you know, then when that fourth year comes around, I'm saying like -- I'm ready. And the other three, three and a half years, you know, I'm like, you know -- you know, I'm not much involved.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: But once it's time to compete and get into the game, I'm there and I love it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And let me say, if that's -- this is the Super Bowl, that's the real Super Bowl.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: That's the real Super Bowl, no doubt about it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Franco, thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Chris.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: My pleasure.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Really appreciate it. Nice being on here with you.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: We want to thank all the Fox at -- folks at Fox News and Fox Sports who helped us report on three big stories today. Keep it right here tonight on your local Fox station as the best team in sports television brings you every moment of Super Bowl LIV. And that's it for today. Have a great week and next week we'll see you next FOX NEWS SUNDAY from snowy New Hampshire. Content and Programming Copyright 2020 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
